title: Low-Temperature Nucleation Behavior of L12 Al3Zr Precipitates in a Dilute Al-Zr-Sn Alloy
content: Dilute Al-Zr alloys are a promising alternative to copper in electric vehicle applications due to balanced strengthening and electrical conductivity (EC) provided by metastable L12-Al3Zr nanoprecipitates [1]. Unfortunately, these alloys require aggressive heat treatments due to the slow diffusion of Zr which results in the sluggish precipitation of L12-Al3Zr [2]. The standard aging heat treatments used for the precipitation of L12-Al3Zr are performed between 375°C and 425°C [2, 3]. In this work, L12-Al3Zr nuclei were observed to form at 200°C in an Al-Zr-Sn alloy due to the formation of β-Sn precipitates. The identity of the L12-Al3Zr nuclei was confirmed by aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and an explanation for L12-Al3Zr nucleation at 200°C where Zr is essentially immobile in Al is presented based on a combination of atom probe tomography (APT) and first-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations.
